reviewText:
Also known as UFO Enemy Unknown. The original (1994) was super buggy and nearly unplayable on newer systems, but thanks to these guys (the people working on the openxcom project) the game is now playable and with lots of bug fixes.

The game is pretty unbalanced and exploitable, here are a few tips:

-  Don't exit the craft in the first turn as the aliens, that have visual on you, will have full AP and will likely reaction fire.
-  Always have the maximum number of soldiers in the landing craft (while this might be obvious, I saw people that don't do this, usually the same kind of people that spend all the APs exploring instead of having some AP for reaction fire or retreat).
- Put the most expandable soldiers closer to the exit of the landing craft because the first ones out are the likeliest to get killed.
- Don't hurry, especially getting your troops out of the landing craft.
- Advance slowly, only extend yourself when you have an alien’s location and you can kill it because you don't want it to have a full turn while you are in sight. Expanding on this, try to kill all the aliens that you see in the same turn that you see them; that's why it's usually best to advance slowly (to have lots of APs) and have lots of soldiers (and implicitly firepower).
- You should use scouts (~rookies) that at the start of the turn will try to advance but also retreat at the end. This way you'll create a buffer and decrease the chance of enemies sneaking close enough to the rest of your (more valuable) soldiers.
- Exploit: After turn 20 the aliens are generally going to come and try to find you, useful for landed/crashed UFOs.
- A very good starting location is in west Lebanon so that you will have cover over Europe and a lot of the downed UFOs could be in North Africa where the desert maps are pretty smooth.
- The beginning (or better said the first half of the game) is going to be pretty brutal, use all the force that you can and don't shy away from explosives and leveling buildings even preemptively in some cases.


Pros: great feeling, nice combination of tactical game, researching stuff and base building while under pressure to survive.
Cons: exploitable, unbalanced, bad spotting/FOV mechanic, you see as much as the aliens only in full light which will lead to a lot of frustration.
Rating: now, we are prodding *them*!
Recommendation: only if you are into this kind of games and you can tolerate/like the graphics.

reviewText:
Originally posted on November 11, 2010

I've been occupied by XCOM for the past two weeks straight, and it's been a blast. XCOM: UFO Defense is simply one of the best games ever made.

The gameplay is deep, addictive and atmospheric, and does a surprising amount for a game from 1994. Your task as leader of the newly formed project for the defense of earth from aliens is to stop alien raids and abductions by shooting down their ships, ambushing their landing parties, and destroying their bases. Eventually you are tasked with taking the fight to the aliens and defeating them altogether. There are two modes of gameplay, the Geoscape and the Battlescape.

In the Geoscape (real time, variable time speeds), you build bases around the world, dispatch interceptors and dropships to deal with UFOs, do research, manufacture and purchase weapons and vehicles, and try to please all your sponsor nations so they don't reduce their funding. However, it quickly becomes apparent that both human technology and the funding from sponsor nations are both completely inadequate for the task. In order to survive and stop the aliens, you need to capture alien technology, research it, and produce your own copies, and then sell the excess loot for mounds of money.

The Battlescape on the other hand (turn based tactical, top down) allows you to control your squad of soldiers (who improve over time in surprisingly sophisticated ways) in attempts to stop the aliens. But don't think it will be easy. The Battlescape is an unforgiving world filled with aliens waiting to snipe at your men from distant cornfields and ambush you from around corners. The first several missions you play, it is likely that you will fail spectacularly. This is entirely intentional, and really contributes to the atmosphere of the game. You really feel like you are learning on the job, facing a totally unknown and technologically superior enemy who holds all the cards. A genuine feeling of satisfaction accompanies finally being able to defeat the aliens in a mission (albeit with heavy losses), or re-engineering your first bit of alien weapon tech. The lack of a tutorial actually helps the game in this way, as it is much deeper than it first appears, and it feels very authentic to learn the ropes of the game in this way.

The graphics and sound are marvelously retro, and might take some getting used to for some of the less open-minded gamers out there, but I assure you the reward is worth it. Overall, this is a game that you MUST play if you call yourself a PC gamer at all. It joins a myriad of other gems from the 90's that modern gamers are continually ignorant of, though they inform modern developers every single day. There is no better indication of the current stagnation of game development than playing a game like XCOM and seeing how incredible it is. This game with an extreme facelift would be strategy GOTY.

It's a free, extensive overhaul with many mod choices built in.   Very easy to set up; you do need to have a vaniilla version (steam version works for me...no disc required, and it is pretty cheap).    Some of the many choices are PSI on/off; improved H. Lasers,  choices for setting up your first base rather than accepting the default, and so on.   Highly recommended.

Ok, the actual review.    It is one of my favorite games of all time (not judging it in its release time frame, but CURRENTLY).      The graphics are last century, iti is true.   But the gameplay is +++++.     It is tough; there is a lot to figure out, and things never seem to happen in an orderly fashion.   Sometimes you just have to give up a mission;  sometimes you just have to give up a game.    The aliens like to win, LoL.   It's a lot of fun to grind through a mission successfully, but there are no guarantees.

One of my criteria for a top notch game is whether it provides not only fun, dangerous stuff to do throughout, but once in a while something unexpected happens that blows me away.   Like  when I found out if I through a grenade on a roof, that it could bounce, and if it bounced into an alley it would fall to the ground, and if there was  a hidden alien there you would hear a muffled explosion and then....the alien death cry  you hardly expected.    First time that happened I had to save and quit for a while...I was laughing too hard.

If you like challenges, tactics, and turn-based games, this is a must try out.   Good luck, andI I hope you can stop those monsters!

reviewText:
X-COM UFO Defense. To clear up some easy confusing this about the original X-COM, not X-COM Enemy Unknown that for some bizarre reason is marketed as UFO Defense in the USA.

UFO Defense was a bona fide classic even back when it was released. You play the role as the supreme commander of earth or some such and must build bases, train troops and research technology as you try to stem the tide of invading aliens. Most of the management aspects take place in a pseudo real-time interface where you look down on the Earth and pick where to build what, which soldiers to send where and so forth. Once you've shot down a UFO or simple found one that's already landed however the game switches down to a Turn-Based tactical map where you must find and eliminate every alien you see. Different elevations, as well as the ability to remove cover and peak into buildings by using explosives keep the game challenging.

As you progress through the game a bit of storyline unfolds as the aliens ramp up their invasion of earth and you are through a series of events lead towards the opportunity to stop it once and for all.

UFO Defense is a classic game that should be played by any fans of strategic/tactical games. It might not have held very well with age but it's still one of the best games in it's genre.

reviewText:
Okay, my original version of this review was terribad so I've decided to redo it to do this game justice. First and foremost, this is one of the best games ever made. It has been over 20 years since this game was originally released and it is still every bit as good now as it was back then. Not even Enemy Unknown (Expect a lot of comparisons by the way) can quite match up to how enthralling this game is.

So let's get some problems out of the way first; As much as I wish XCOM: Enemy Unknown would let you have more than a maximum of 6 soldiers in a mission at once, this game goes completely ♥♥♥♥ing overboard with it. At first it's not too bad, letting you initially field 14 soldiers a mission at once. It gives you a generous amount of troops without it being too unwieldy. However late game once you get the final transport you can field 26 soldiers a mission. This not only makes soldiers feel a little too expendable (Which can lead to some pretty hilarious things to happen when your higher ranking officers are in trouble) it also makes some battles incredibly laborious especially when you're unloading your troops from the transport. Then there is the user interface which will be completely baffling for new players. Seriously, it can take a while to actually get used to it. If you can get past it, though, then I guarantee you will fall in love with this game.

Okay now that that is out of the way; The actual strategic battles that take place are perfect. Fully destructable environments combined with every weapon being able to freely target any tile adds countless strategic value and can make or break any situation. Then there is the time units system. As great as the two move system in Enemy Unknown is, it doesn't exactly work as well as the time unit system in UFO Defense. Let me explain: Time units act as a kind of currency given to each unit on the field in order to perform any action be it moving, crouching, shooting, or looting. Oh yeah, that's another thing that's better about this game, you can loot dead enemies as well as fallen XCOM soldiers. This is a really good feature that allows you to have tiny victories by letting you take some alien artifacts or carcasses even when the aliens have almost completely annihilated your forces. Then there is also the game's night missions. Unlike in Enemy Unknown, depending on where the battlefield is taking place, night missions can be legitimately creepy and frustratingly difficult early game. It helps to build this really tense atmosphere that even in late game still retains a little bit of its magic, and it's only amplified if there's a chryssalid lurking around.

Okay now let's move on to the Geoscape... well there is a lot more micro management in this part than both the Battlescape and Enemy Uknown combined. I personally like it; it makes me feel more like I'm running a military base with all the little things that ultimately don't add much value to the overall game, but are pretty nice to have anyway. However I will always always ALWAYS prefer this Geoscape over Enemy Unknown's Geoscape. Why? Because this Geoscape actually let's you be proactive by letting you patrol your interceptors over areas that seem to have a lot of UFO activity instead of that god awful satelite mechanic in Enemy Unkown (which I will explain in more detail why it is bad in my review of Enemy Unknown once I finish the game.) The interceptor battles themselves don't have much more depth in this game, but they go by so fast it's not a glaring issue. Also, deploying your troops to deal with aliens doesn't run as much of a risk of losing a country's support as it does in Enemy Unknown, and as a result makes the aftermath of the council report much less annoying.

There are some things that I haven't addressed about this game in this review, but it's already long enough and I feel I've covered all the important stuff... Even if this turned into an old XCOM vs new XCOM, but after playing both games a lot it's really hard for me not to compare them. It's still amazing how well this game has aged over a couple decades as opposed to others, and I still stand by what I said in the first paragraph that XCOM: UFO Defense is one of the greatest games of all time.
10/10 (Because I can't refrain myself from giving games I review a score)

reviewText:
X-Com is a game I have become very fond of long after it's time has passed.
As a squad tactics turn-based strategy game, it's by no means for the faint-hearted, as overly-aggressive tactics are almost always promptly punished with the loss of one (or more) of your own units.  This is a game where being OCD can usually pay off.

Featuring a massive tech tree for both the aircraft to shoot down UFOs, and for your ground forces to have better weapons and armor to defeat whatever aliens may actually make it to the ground, not to mention the amount of detail put into the game's research entries, the game has a sound amount of content.

The actual combat is solid, featuring mostly destructable terrain, and a lot of gratification for successful operations, and plenty of chaos for a turn-based game.  It's detailed enough for a strategy-game fan to get immersed in, if he/she so wished.

All in all, it's an often-overlooked gem that I believe everyone should play at least once.

reviewText:
I have completed the game at super human difficulty short after initial release.

X-COM is the father of all turn based, tactical squad combat games and still today far deeper than modern games of the kind, although few.

Compared to the new release of X-COM which is the closest modern game available, UFO Defence is back on graphics, modern interface, tutorial and simplicity, but if you do not mind graphics and tutorial and like to venture deep into finding a complex game secrets in tactical squad combat and out of combat strategic decisions, UFO Defence is not a choice, it is your only choice.

X-COM in terms if time and what you see is the exact opposite of total war games, the 'map' which is the entire planet runs in real time or faster if you choose, and when you take any action like bases management or entering combat time pauses. In combat you play in turns, all other actions out of combat like base management are simply interface choices at paused global time.

Starting up, you have an underground base with some basic few equipment and personell. You job is to deal with alien threat on earth. To do that you need to intercept UFOs with you planes when you detect them so you crash them and then land and explore with your squad. Also you need to react to other alien activities already on ground like city attacks. At the end, you squad lands near the incident, kills alien opposition and accomplishes the goals. But kill the alien opposition is not exactly easy. The second part is about three main activities. Research on alien equipment, dead and alive aliens and theories will give you knowledge for better combat effectiveness, stronger bases and progress your investigation on aliens and to understand your enemy plan - the initial title was UFO Enemy uknown. The second is manufacturing, usually based on alien findings after researching. You can manufacture weapons, armor and gadgets for your combat squad, plane fighters and their weapons for stronger interceptions, better squad carrier crafts, base facilities and defences and other. The third thing is about your bases. You start with one but you can build 8 total.

The magic about X-COM is that you can do anything that later X-COM or X-COM like games restrict and present them as new revolutionary gameplay elements. But for X-COM veterans those were just restrictions. You can have a fully custom squad, from 1 man show to 32 total soldiers, replacing 4 with a mechanical small tank if you like, or two or as many tanks as you like, soldiers equipped with whatever gear from a large variaty of existing and later researched and manufactured options. You can complete a mission with dozens of real different tactics. You can expand your bases any way you like. You can build a 'research' base, or a 'factory' base or an 'interception' base or a 'military' base as i call them. Or just all your bases can be all-around.

As a matter of fact, any style you want to play is doable. And every choice has effect. A tank unit for example is definatetly stronger than a soldier at start but it does not gain any experience. Soldiers improve mostly after they kill aliens. On the other hand, if you have the transportation space you may get a tank with you to salvage the situation if all goes ill. Or just do not use tanks - i do not for example. They are not overpowered or anything, but i do not like them, i prefer soldiers.

reviewText:
Remember that show you watched as a kid about that super secret elite fighting force that protected the earth against an evil menace that wanted to destroy/take over the Earth? This is about those guys.
You play as a paramilitary organization tasked with defending the Earth from an alien invasion. Of course, the bad news is that the aliens equipment is extreamly more advanced than what you can field in the beginning so its up to you to even the odds. Gameplay takes place in two screens, the Geocape which is where you manage your bases, conduct research, launch missions, and monitor alien activity across the globe.
The second screen is the Battlescape. This is where you take the fight to the aliens.
Gameplay here is turn based as you move your troops around the battlefield trying to kill aliens before they shoot your troops in the face with a plasma bolt.
You will shake your fists in anger as your rookie trooper fails to shoot a sectoid that is right in front of him. You will morn the death of your favorite veteran soldier when they die heroically in the line of duty, you will smile with glee when you finish building a shiney new weapon that you reverse engineered from alien tech and prepare to use it against the alien menace, and you will shreik in terror when you experiance a snakeman terror mission for the first time.

This game maybe old, but it is a must play for any fan of strategy games out there.

(Recently, OpenXcom was released which adds a whole bunch of features (including mod support) and bug fixes that is a must have if you play this game. OpenXcom is a free download so feel free to get it after you buy this game.)

reviewText:
Said to be the best strategy game of all time. Not an understatement exactly. It's not as needlessly complex as most turn based strategy games. It's not as hectic as realtime strategy and it's not as shallow as most indie strategy out today. This is a really well balanced strategy game with destructable environments, funding, research, base maintenence and manufacturing. Very entertaining game and well worth the price.

Story - What's it all about?
X-COM starts on January, 1999. You are in charge of X-COM, an extraterrestrial defense force, funded by almost all of the major countries from back in the 90ies. Russia, Brazil, China, USA, India, South Africa, Libya, Egypt and all of the major european countries like France, Germany, UK and not some others like any Nordic ones or Netherlands, Austria. Probably because these countries wouldn't or couldn't fund a project such as an extraterrestrial defense force. Regardless, you are now supposed to cover the 'entire globe'. Well not entire, you will only have to cover the ones that do fund you and since many countries actually doesn't fund you, you can safely let aliens land in their areas. But if you're like me, you will probably want to go ahead and cover as much territory as possible anyway.

Gameplay - How does it play?
You are in charge of everything. You put up your base, you intercept and shoot down all of the UFOs, you lead your tactical squads on mission, conduct research and manufacture weapons. This game is amazing in all you can do and research is vitally important to you as it leads your progress throughout the game (like research bloody should!). At the start of the game you know nothing about these aliens and even as a player that kinda frightens you because these aliens, already from the absolute start of the game, they utilize far more superior weapons than your own. As the game progresses, the aliens don't really, but if you're able to stay in the game for long enough and have spent some fair amount of money in scientists you will realize that you can reverse engineer the alien technology and even construct even more superior weapons than them: GENIUS!

Criticism - But what isn't that great?
Well for instance, the aliens start out vastly superior to your people in every respect. This is not bad in of itself but it makes some of the future things you can construct somewhat redundant. For instance; you can construct armor for your soldiers eventually, but it doesn't protect well as the aliens fire incredibly damaging salvos of plasma matter at them which basically melts the armor instantly. Without the armor your soldiers only have 1 hit point as far as you're concerned but even with the armor they barely raise that to 2 hit points. Also, when one of your people dies; you cannot recover their armor. Which means that you must make a 20000 dollar armor for every individual you want to protect.
My other criticism with the game is that many of the expenses doesn't make much sense. For instance; you never buy interception planes. No you RENT them! What the earth? And when they get shot down (not if), you don't even have to pay anything. I think they could just as well have sold the interceptors instead, but seeing as it is the very first plane for a very long time I can see why they decides to make the planes that way. The funny thing is that the rent of bloody 600'000 dollars and you have to pay every month! I know it's state of the art but holy cow man. USA's funding is barely 700'000 - 800'000 and they expect you to have a base there plus at least one interceptor to keep all of the aliens at bay!?
Of course I am nitpicking a little but that's what great with the game: It doesn't really have any flaws other than that. Sure the aliens are hard as balls to fight but that's the point of the game!

Conclusion - So what rating do you propose?
I propose a rating of 6 out of 6. This game is bloody amazing strategy game. It's almost as if it was made for me. The amount of content in it is huge for a DOS game of barely 6 MB and even by today's standards it's incredibly fun to play.

reviewText:
X-COM: UFO Defense is an often revered classic in strategy cirlces, more so now than ever before following Firaxis' re-interpretation of the series in their Enemy Unknown 2012 release.

Despite being nearly twenty years old, the 4X strategy aspects are as strong as ever. I appreciate how the interface and geoscape are presented to you with next to no hand-holding. The lack of any sort of tutorial or battle advice works effectively in immersing you in a reality where your enemy threats are truly alien and in every sense of the word too. Experimentation is key, with base building allowing for different types of manufacture and research that have plentiful bounties to offer. The X-COM unit itself can be treated as if a business of it's own which naturally has numerous benefits throughout the course of the game.

Yet the actual combat itself is where UFO Defence shows it's true colours, irrespective of how prepared you really are. It doesn't matter what armour you have, what guns you carry or even how experienced your soldiers are: the struggle always remains the same. Your units will miss painfully obvious shots, be felled by a single stray bullet or, most embarassingly of all, panic at the mere sight of a lone alien mook. It is because of the haphazard nature of X-Com's combat that it can feel slow and monotnous, especially as level structures repeat themselves and saves are reloaded numerous times in order to better chances against otherwise unbeatable enemies. Some people love X-COM's combat but I'm most certainly not one of them

Even so, UFO Defense was a major sign-post for the strategy genre because it took these crucial features in the combat and global contest and extended them into a larger experience. Not many games to this day match X-COM for it's scale and even fewer for it's initially brutal learning curve either. Most of you reading this have probably already made up your mind about the series and it's legacy either way, to those who haven't I would only recommend you try them simply to say you've done so. If nothing else, X-COM is capable of eating up weeks of spare-time when it engrosses the best of us and that genuinely is a good thing.

reviewText:
After Minecraft, X-COM UFOD is my favorite game of all time. In fact it may be no coincidence that both games share common traits: they both have stellar gameplay and horrible graphics. Most game developers today seem to have forgotten a simple truth- Gameplay > Graphics. XCOM gives you command of an army of super-soldiers to fight off an alien invasion. Micro-managing is the key to victory and boy....there is plenty of that. You decide everything from where your bases will be / how large or small to how many bullets each soldier carries. The combat is turn-based and the enemy AI , while not as good as later games , can still be very sneaky.

What I enjoyed most is how your soldiers *slowly* ramp up in strength via reverse engineering of captured alien tech. There are times when ( if you havent been researching fast enough) you may encounter stronger aliens and still be useing simple guns! Defeating these stonger aliens with current weapons are the great story-making events of the XCOM game.

Oh did I mention the RPG elements too? Each soldier in your army has his/ her own stats. These stats can determine things like what weapon they would be best at, if they would make a great scout, a good medic, or if they should be sent packing.

Any fan of RPG + Turn-base + Sci Fi games simply cannot go wrong with this title.


Rivscore- 99 / 100

++NOTE++ Yes. That's right...99 out of 100. This game is almost perfect. If the Devs would pay for Scarlett Johanson to come to my next birthday party and blow...out my candles it would be 100 / 100.

reviewText:
This game is a gem for its time, maybe even one of the best - yet most complex and demanding - pieces ever created on personal computer. Hopefully the presented claim is only little exaggeration. *UFO Defense* gameplay includes multiple aspects such as financial and supply management, base construction planning, research and manufacture organisation, big view world-defense with hypersonic jet planes and later innovative solutions; soldier recruitment and training, as well as turn-based tactical ground combat that the reviewed product pioneered in great extent. Recovery of alien artifacts and technology with their adaptation to Earth-based equipment is crucial to ones development in pursuit of defeating an enemy, whose abilities and ravagery increase with time.

Memories of fine hours dedicated to exploring the world endangered by alien invasion - and its only shield, the international X-COM force - brought me back to this product. I am still under impression of its uniqueness. Nevertheless, for present day, this DosBox version - that STEAM claims to be Windows-compatible - is far from working acceptably. Five euro/dollars for a program older than twenty years is robbery considering the current standards. If you are going to buy *UFO Defense*, do it only for the sake of *OpenXcom* - a fan-made and well done upgrade that greatly enchances the playability of the game, next to optimizing it for modern systems. *OpenXcom* requires the original *UFO Defense* data. Know, yet, that this data are remote files that ought to be available for free already.

Is this game difficult? Whether it is difficult or easy for someone who already knows how to play it, is one thing - but to learn how to play it on minimum required level, is other thing - and that may be tough; be warned. It is a nostalgia purchase nowadays. User-friendliness is hardly a feature here.

I truly admire *UFO Defense*, as well as impressive input that the fandom had into making it so much better experience, therefore I need to be fair with what we get on STEAM at the moment [2016] for the price of five euro/dollars: thumbs down. DosBox version is out of play.

Certainly a classic, but a product of its own time
I can see why this game and its sequels are so revered: the sheer scope of your options is so vast and varied, you really get the feeling that you're a part of a much larger world, and it's not simply a game script feeding you pre-determined scenarios.

However, this is one of those very old games that have unwritten rules" that you only come by after repeated attempts at trial and error (e.g. always use "Auto Shot" instead of "Aimed Shot
date:
dedicate your resarch to such-and-such immediately, don't use tanks because they're useless, etc.). Given the complexity of this game, you can expect to lose many, many times before making the tiniest smidge of progress. Even the many FAQs and walkthroughs that exist give contradictory information (not to mention that one shouldn't have to consult a walkthrough just to be able to play a game).

I can imagine that when this came out in the sparse game market of the mid-90s, that it was absolutely amazing. I suspect a lot of the positive reviews for it come from people who played it when it first came out. Back then, you wouldn't mind spending hours upon hours playing, even if you were defeated each time. However, games have advanced considerably since then, and its outdated mechanics and unforgiving gameplay make it downright frustrating for new players. Losing is rarely fun.

Short version:
If you're looking for a fun strategy game, I recommend buying the reboot, X-COM: Enemy Unknown. It preserves what was great about the original series with updated, simplified mechanics.
If you heard this is a classic and you're curious, I recommend watching a Let's Play of it instead. Those people have played it before and know the right" way to play the game. It will save you time AND grief!

So I finally am sitting down to try out these well renowned classics. First stop is the original X-Com: UFO Defense.
Right off the bat I have to give props to whoever was behind the porting. The game runs beautifully and even scales well on a full 1080p display. The sound also is fully functional with only some minor skipping in the opening cutscene. If you were into this game and have a lot of nostalgia for it, then you will love this masterful port.
As a brand new player of the X-Com games, I can’t say I have much interest in this original title. I have no doubts that it was a phenomenal experience back upon release, but some games age better than others and the rose tint of nostalgia goggles only works for games you grew up with. UFO Defense has no semblance of a tutorial. I have a feeling that the original game had an awesome manual (as all classic titles did) but Steam doesn’t sell games in boxes. Without a tutorial I had to do a lot of trial and error. Fortunately I understand the premise of the game, but even knowing how the game is supposed to play out I was constantly struggling with the interface and cryptic icons. It took almost 30 minutes of play before I was ever able to see the ground combat and once the mission was underway I quickly lost all patience for the interface. I’m spoiled from all the advancement in interface design and increase in screen real estate, trying to navigate the battlefield and direct my soldiers was nothing but frustrating.
X-Com: UFO Defense was the spark that started one of gaming's classic and highly regarded franchises but I don’t think it’s aged well. The port is phenomenal and those who grew up with it will be thrilled with this trip down memory lane. However, newcomers will more than likely be put off.

One of the greatest PC games of all time.  It dominated large chunks of my childhood, and despite the outdated graphics, MIDI sound(which still holds up for the most part if you ask me), fairly brutal user interface, and occasional catasrophic bugs while emulating it on a modern rig, it still gets thrown into the mix every few years and played start to finish.

If you can overlook it's technical problems, and punishing difficulty, and have any imagination whatsoever, it's a great, deep, long ride with endless replayability.  If you can't overlook these things, its second sequel Armageddon, when played in TBS in the tactiacal mode, offers an improved gameplay experience, if IMO a sightly inferior story and over-extended endgame.  The original can't be beat.

Take my advice, and rename your soldiers after friends and family as they start getting promoted past the rookie level, and increasing in skill.  It lends a visceral edge to the gameplay.  You'll flesh out the story for yourself with your squad's triumphs and tragedies as they combat the greatest threat the world has ever faced in the far-flung future of 1999.

While the mechanics of tactical combat may not have aged so well, the startegic component of the game is still quite strong.  You coordinate the clandestine worldwide effort to combat a semi-secret alien invasion of earth by tracking, interdicting, and destroying alien craft, researching the invaders and their tech while repurposing it for your own use, and perhaps selling it on the black market to fund X-COM operations.  You may need an extra source of income, as you'll find yourself managing a worldwide network of secret bases employing the best of the Earth's scientific, engineering, and military resources.  That doesn't come cheap, and if you don't produce results, you may find your cash flow from the council of funding nations diminishing, or drying up entirely as the individual members cut their contributions, or drop out of the project entirely to sign a pact with the aliens, giving them another base of Earthly operations.  You've got to keep your elite, multinational, squads of Spec-Ops soldiers supplied with the lastest in life-saving, or death-dealing alien technology as they investigate UFO crash and landing sites, recover advanced alien technology, defend the helpless populations of Earth's terrorized towns and cities composed of several distict terrain types in randomly-generated tactical missions.  You'll use what they discover and recover during these missions and back at your on-base laboritories to finally be able to gain the upper hand and take the fight to the aliens in their hidden bases on Earth, as you strive to kick them out of the solar system once and for all.

Seriously.  This game rocks.  Often imitated, but to my knowledge, never excelled to this day.  If you're not a graphics snob, have ever enjoyed a turn-based strategy game, and you have a few dollars(and potentially lots of time) to spend, you have no excuse not to try it now that it's on Steam.  There's a reason people make DOS emulators for modern machines.  This game is the best reason to download one.

The original X-COM game is quite simply one of the finest turn-based tactical games I've ever played. The game blends high-level global strategy with the small-scale tactical challenge of skirmish battles for a still-unmatched gaming experience.
The mechanics behind the tactical battles are incredibly detailed, and provide nearly unlimited flexibility and choice. For example, all terrain is destructible, your fighters have nearly unlimited choice of actions (they may even toss out-of-ammo friends additional magazines or even whole loaded weapons!) and each battle presents unique challenges. You command a small squad of approximately a dozen soldiers who gain experience, improve their abilities and accrue injuries over the course of the campaign. Missions are as diverse as clearing UFO crash sites and recovering alien artifacts, defending populated areas from alien terror attacks, raiding functional enemy vessels or ground bases and even defending your own base(s) of operations from a determined enemy attack! Each of these tactical battles is important to the global strategy component, so you don't want to lose a battle as it may have lasting consequences to the rest of the game, but by the same token sometimes you won't even be able to show up to a particular engagement as you are forced to pick your battles in order to win the war! For example, you may be more concerned with protecting a country that provides substantial income for you than one who is less monetarily crucial to you. Later in the campaign you can manage your greater resources to allow you to build additional bases, allowing coverage of more of the globe so that hopefully you won't have to make such compromises.
In addition to this you have the capacity to expand each base's facilities, increasing the number of fighters and transports at your disposal, or expanding your research or production capabilities. Research is an important aspect of the game, as you gather alien technology and reverse engineer working models for your soldiers to use in battle. As you progress up the alien tech tree new weapons and armour will be made available for you to produce, most of which outperforms your meager Earth technology. You might even start making ends meet, financially speaking, by selling some of the valuable alien tech you discover (or even create...) on the black market to the discerning, and wealthy, private collectors of the world!
The game's greatest failings (and they certainly do exist) are almost invariably caused by its clunky user interface and painstaking inability to remember previous choices. For example, performing actions with your fighters takes ages to complete - part of this is the price of such unparalleled flexibility, but part of it is just poor design. Worse than this though, you must equip each of your soldiers before every battle. The computer seems to randomly assign them the gear available, and then you need to sort through each and every one of them, removing gear, assigning it to another soldier, then giving them the correct equipment which the game gave to another soldier. It is tedious and would be an immense waste of time but for the fact that if you don't do it, no one will have the correct weapons at the start of the fight!
Bear in mind that those literally the only complaints I have against the game - it's otherwise poor graphical quality is forgiven on account of its venerable age, and its at-first opaque controls require a thorough read of the game manual to explain them (though this is available through steam). I would strongly recommend new players visit the X-COM wiki in order to familiarize yourself with the game, its controls and the mechanics before having a go, as its complexity can be daunting at first. However, once you get beyond that initial uncertainty the game yields endless rewards for anyone willing to play it through to completion!

Long: To begin, the Windows 7 version runs via DosBox. The default settings limit the cycle speed, meaning the game can have very low FPS counts sometimes. Manually changing the cycle limit will allow you to increase the FPS for smoother gameplay.

The controls via DosBox are all cursor-based, as far as I know. The keyboard is simply not used at all. Keyboard controls could be useful, so I will say this is a con.

The game itself has tons of options for players. There are some base management aspects, where you can build new facilities in the X-COM bases or build new bases altogether. This stuff is pretty simple (not really any micro managing) but allows for a large variety of different base configurations. Supplies and personel (soldiers, scientists, and engineers) can be bought/hired and sold/fired and can also be transferred between bases. Scientists research new technology from base labs which can allow your engineers to manufactor new weapons, vehicles, armor, or other useful things. Funding is a concern; your funding is automatically adjusted each month based on your performance in stopping the alien menace. You can also gain funds by selling supplies you find or produce.

reviewText: My favorite game ever.  The (pioneering) combination of tactical combat, with strategic base management, makes the game very non-linear.  I originally played this back before FAQs and Strategy Guides, so learning the research tree by trial and error was quite facinating.  The 2012 remake was a faithful remake, but this is the one that I will always come back to.  You as a player have to remember all the trivial aspects, such as remembering to save time for returning your soldiers to cover, crouching, and having time for overwatch.  Your soldiers have a high mortality rate, but (while alive) they have many individual statistics and personal growth.  It is easy to get familiar with a character, just to watch the character die in a later mission.

Well, despite being one of the best strategy games of all time, it does have some rough patches.

XCOM: Ufo Defence (originally released as UFO: Enemy Unknown in Europe and Australia) is a critically acclaimed Strategy Game published in 1993 by MicroProse, the company behind the release of other great classic titles such as Transport Tycoon Deluxe, Worms Armageddon and Sid Meier's Pirates!

XCOM (Extraterrestrial Combat Unit) is a top secret paramilitary organisation internationally funded by nations around the world. It's sole purpose is to combat a growing extraterrestrial threat on Earth and investigate the reasoning behind this.

Unlike many other Strategy games, XCOM is a blend of micromanagement and turn based combat. When not in combat, players are thrown into a real-time management stage where they can allocate and coordinate their resources towards fighting the aliens. This includes researching new technology, studying alien artifacts, constructing bases and recruiting personel.

XCOM is unique strategy game. It's no surprise IGN rates it as the #1 PC game of all time.

Probably the best game created ever.  Hands down.  There was nothing like it before and while many tried to be like it, none could do it properly.

If you overlook the outdated graphics, you still get the best strategy game created.  Every decision you make matters and every event large or small is important.  You start out woefully underequipped and inexperienced to deal with the alien invasion.  Your soldiers suffer massive casualties when you start out from the disparity in equipment you would expect between current earth tech vs an invading alien.  Every soldier lost hurts, but not nearly as much as the loss of your long-term survivors who become stronger with every rank.  Losing a corporal stings, but losing a colonel hurts.  Sometimes the only solution is to throw lots of soldiers at the aliens and hope at least 2 or 3 survive to go on, but it's a desperate time and you have to make the hard choices.  The fate of the Earth is in your hands!

I still play this version at times just for the trip down memory lane back to a time when you could sink hundreds of hours into a game and still lose!  None of that easy wins in games like you see now.  To win this game, you worked for it and you put in the time to do it.

Everyone who does strategy games needs to own this one to see where games today got their inspirations and how this one game changed pc gaming for all time.
